text: An isotype - specific activator of major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) class II genes that is independent of <extra_id_0> class II transactivator <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Patients with one type of major histocompatibility complex class II combined immunodeficiency have mutations in a gene termed <extra_id_0> class II transactivator <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , which coordinately controls the transcription of the three major human class II genes , HLA-DR , - DQ , and - DP .

However , the experimentally derived B-lymphoblastoid cell line , clone 13 , expresses high levels of HLADQ in the absence of HLA-DR and HLA-DP , despite its mapping by complementation analysis to this group .
It was possible that one of the clone 13 <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> alleles bore a mutation that allowed HLA-DQ , but not HLA-DR or - DP transcription .
Alternatively , another factor , distinct from <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , might control HLA-DQ expression .

We report here that ectopic expression of <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cDNAs derived by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction from clone 13 do not restore expression of HLA-DQ in another <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient cell line , RJ2.2.5 .
In addition , no <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein is detectable in clone 13 nuclear extracts .
In contrast , somatic cell fusion between clone 13 and RJ2.2.5 restored expression of the HLA-DQ haplotype encoded by the RJ2.2.5 DQB gene .
Taken together , these data demonstrate the existence of an HLA-DQ isotype - specific trans - acting factor , which functions independently of <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
